A law of composition on a set $M$ is a map from $M \times M$ to $M$. It is characterized by the assignment $(a, b) \longmapsto a \cdot b$ for $(a, b) \in M \times M$, and in many cases, the image of a given pair $(a, b)$ is written as a "product" $a \cdot b$ or $ab$.

The Klein four-group, denoted as $\mathfrak{V}_{4}$, is a subgroup of $\mathfrak{S}_{4}$ consisting of the permutations $\{\mathrm{id}, (1,2)(3,4), (1,3)(2,4), (1,4)(2,3)\}$. It is isomorphic to $\mathbb{Z} / 2 \mathbb{Z} \times \mathbb{Z} / 2 \mathbb{Z}$.
Does the concept of a/an Law of Composition need to be defined for a definition of a/an Klein Four-Group to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The Klein Four-Group is defined as a specific subgroup of permutations within the symmetric group \\(\mathfrak{S}_{4}\\). To understand and work with any group, including the Klein Four-Group, it is essential to have a law of composition defined. This law of composition in the context of a group is the operation that combines any two elements of the group to produce another element of the group. In the case of the Klein Four-Group, the law of composition is the operation of permutation multiplication. Without a law of composition, the structure of the group cannot be defined because it is the operation that allows the group elements to interact and satisfy the group axioms (closure, associativity, identity, and inverses). Therefore, the concept of a law of composition is necessary for the definition of the Klein Four-Group to make sense, as it provides the fundamental operation that defines the group structure.
